textBox.richText: What made me start focusing on the study of genocide was teaching it. In my first three weeks of teaching, I had put together a lecture on the Armenian genocide. I thought, naively, that I had presented the information in a way that would interest students. I was faced with two direct challenges: one student raised her hand and said, “But Mrs. Bylo, some of us just don’t care.” Another, a boy raised in Turkey, laughed that I had been taken in by false claims by the Armenian community and that I obviously didn’t have any clue what happened. But, these two students were not alone. Instead they were merely representing two major problems in the history of genocide. I have put together a small list dealing with issues in memory on the page Bibliography of Memory & Genocide. Again, many thanks to Adam Jones.
